As featured in the first chapter of Kotronias's book, which suggests it's the line he considers least effective.  My memory of the detailed lines is vague but I've usually followed a policy of alternating pawn and minor piece moves over the next few moves, which hasn't served me particularly well.  In this game I concentrated on developing my pieces before launching too many pawns.

The pawns on f5 and h5 exercise a powerful grip on Black's kingside but they also get in White's way.  White's king is also more exposed that Black's, but White's pieces are better poised to attack, so it's still a double-edged position.
